XII. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all and every person and persons who shall after the time appointed as aforesaid for the surrender of any person or persons so charged upon oath with any of the offences aforesaid, shall be expired, harbour, receive, conceal, aid, abet, or succour such person or persons, knowing him or them to have been so charged as aforesaid, and to have been required to surrender him or themselves by such order or orders, as aforesaid, and not to have surrendered pursuant to such order or orders, being prosecuted for the fame, within one year after the offence committed, and lawfully convicted thereof, shall be guilty of felony, and shall be trans-ported as a felon or felons for the space of seven years, in the same manner as felons are or Hull be appointed to be transported, by virtue of any act or acts already made or hereafter to be made touching the transportation of felons; and if any such offender or offenders shall be found at large within this kingdom before the expiration of the said term, without lawful cause, he, flic, or they shall suffer death as felons, and have execution awarded against him, her, or them as persons attainted of felony without benefit of clergy.

XXXI. And whereas doubts have arisen, whether salt brought inveffels for the purpose of curing lish caught on the coast of this kingdom, be subject to duty in like manner as the fame would be if actually landed in this kingdom: be it therefore declared and enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the passing of this act, all salt brought on the coast of this kingdom, or within three leagues thereof, shall be subject to the like duty that such salt would be subject to if the fame was actually landed in this kingdom: and in case any ship, vessel, or boat, with salt on board shall be on any part of the coast of this kingdom, or within three leagues thereof, for the space of twenty four hours, and shall not invoice the said salt, and pay duty for the fame, then and in every such case all such salt shall be forfeited, and it shall and may be lawful for any officer of the revenue to seize all such salt as shall he found on board such ship, vessel, or boat, and to detain such ship, vessel, or boat in which the salt shall be so found, until the said salt shall be unladen.

XLII. Provided always, That nothing herein contained shall extend to any person or persons who deal in and fell wine in quantities, not less titan one gallon, or nutmegs, mace, cloves, or cinnamon, drugs, dying stuffs, and the materials of manu-fadurc.

XLIII. And whereas several ill disposed persons do frequently dye, fabricate, or manufacture very great quantities of floe leaves, liquorish leaves, and the leaves of tea that have been before used, or the leaves of other trees, (lirubs, or plants in imitation of tea, and do likewise mix, colour, stain, and dye such leaves, and likewise tea with Terra Japonica, sugar, molasses, clay, logwood, and with other ingredients, and do fell and vend the same as true and real tea, to the prejudice of the health of his Majesty's subjects, the diminution of the revenue, and to the ruin of the fair trader; for remedy of such frauds and abuses for the future, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty five, if any person or persons shall dye, fabricate, or manufacture any floe leaves, liquorice leaves, or the leaves of tea that have been used, or the leaves of any other tree, Ihrub, or plant in imitation of tea, or shall mix, colour, stain, or dye such leaves or tea with Terra Japonica, sugar, molasses, clay, logwood, or with any other ingredients or materials whatsoever, or shall fell and vend, or utter, offer, or expose to sale, or shall have in his, her, or their custody or possession any such dyed, fabricated, or manufactured leaves in imitation of tea, or any such coloured, stained, or dyed leaves, or tea mixed with any of the ingredients before mentioned, or with any other ingredients whatsoever, such person or persons shall respectively for every pound of such leaves so dyed, fabricated, or manufactured in imitation of tea; and for every pound of such mixed, coloured, stained, or dyed leaves or tea, forfeit and pay- the sum of ten pounds, together with all such leaves or tea, which leaves or tea any officer or officers of his Majesty's revenue is and are hereby required and empowered to seize.

XLIV. Whereas there are high duties payable on the importation of tallow into this kingdom, and it would be highly conducive to the manufacture of soap and candles in this kingdom, and to the exportation of those commodities if the import of the said commodities was encouraged by lessening the duty thereof

The twenty fifth Year of George III.

of: be it therefore enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after- the passing of this act there shall be paid for every one hundred weight of tallow, the sum of six pence on the importation thereof into this kingdom, and no more; any law or statute to the contrary thereof in any wise notwithstanding.

XLVII. Whereas doubts have arisen as to the duty of custom payable on the importation of oil of the produce of Sevil, Majorca, Minorca, Apuglia, Provence, or Portugal: and whereas the duty imposed by the act of customs, on such articles is a duty of two pounds twelve shillings per ton, if imported by natural horn subjects, and if imported by strangers or aliens, a duty of three pounds live shillings per ton: and whereas it is thought reasonable, that the duty imposed on such oil by the said act of customs, should he the only duty of custom payable thereon: be it therefore declared and enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all such oil imported into this kingdom by natural born subjects, shall pay a duty of custom after the rate of two pounds twelve shillings per ton only, and if such oil shall be imported by strangers or aliens, a duty of custom shall be paid, after the rate of three pounds five shillings per ton only, any law or custom to the contrary notwithstanding.

XLIX. And whereas it has sometimes happened upon the trial of offences against the laws of this kingdom, before lub-commissioners of excise, that the fub-commissioners have alter their court has been opened, and the trial begun, adjourned the court and trial, merely for their own convenience, without any application for that purpose, on the behalf of the parties, or either of them, and without any cause assigned on oath, to jliftify such adjournment, to the great injury and delay both of the crown and subject: for remedy whereof, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty five, it shall not be lawful for any court of fub-commissioners to adjourn the hearing of any caul'e actually begun, unless from day to day, for the purpose of further hearing such cause, (Sundays excepted) unless by the consent of both parties, or upon some good and sufficient cause to be assigned upon oath by one of the parties applying for such adjournment, or his, her, or their counsel, agent, or solicitor, or unless upon some good and sufficient cause to be assigned upon oath: by one or more of the said fub-commissioners, if any adjourn-iinent shall be desired and applied for by him or them.

LXI. And whereas by the said act passed in the twenty fil'd and twenty second years of his Majesty's reign, it was enacted, That no person should be licensed to carry on the trade of diddling spirits unless such person should first enter into a bond to his MajeC-ty, his heirs and successors, in the penalty of two hundred pounds, conditioned to pay excise for one hundred and twelve working days in each year, that is to say, for twenty eight days in each quarter of the year therein mentioned: and whereas there are certain seasons in the year when the process of diddling may not be carried on with such advantage to distillers as at other seasons, and it will equally answer the purpose of the said act if such distillers pay excise according to the rules and regulations herein contained for any one hundred and twelve working days in each year: be it therefore enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no person shall be licensed to carry on the trade of diddling spirits, unless such person shall fird enter into a bond to his Majesty, his heirs and successors, in the penalty of two hundred pounds, conditioned to pay excise for one hundred and twelve working days in each year, from the time of obtaining his licence, according to the rules and regulations herein contained; and that such bond be taken in lieu of the bond so prescribed by the said receited act as aforesaid; any thing therein contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

LXII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty fix, no licence for keeping any dill or dills which shall not be of the content of five hundred gallons or upwards, shall be granted by the chief commissioners, or any officer of his Majesty's revenue, except to apothecaries, drug-gids and persons for diddling medicinal waters as now by law may be; any former act or acts to the contrary notwithstanding.

LXV. Provided always, That no drawback on any one gallon of spirits or brandies, Aiall exceed in the whole the sum of thirteen pence.

LXVI. WHEREAS a well regulated fishery is the most fruitful nursery of hardy seamen: and whereas the great resort of fish to the coasts of this kingdom, offers this advantage in a degree superior to other nations: and whereas various' laws have been parted, and extraordinary bounties granted, in order to encourage tills great source of naval strength, but the object of the laws has been eluded, and the bounties have been frequently claimed for vessels not employed in the iilheries, or if employed therein, the owners have neglected to cure the fish in a merchantable manner, and thereby brought Irish cured fish into disrepute at foreign markets: and whereas an act passed in this kingdom in the seventh year of his late Majesty King George the second, entitled. An act for the farther encouragement of the ffheries of this kingdom; and also another act passed in this kingdom in the third year of his present Majesty King George the third, entitled, An act for the encouragement of the ffheries of this kingdom; and also another act passed in the fifth year of his present Majesty, entitled, An act for explaining and amending an aS, entitled. An act for the encouragement of the ffheries of this kingdom; and all'o another act passed in this kingdom in the seventeenth and eighteenth years of his present Majesty, entitled, An act to explain and amend the aSs made for the encouragement of the ffheries of this kingdom: and for promoting the good ends proposed by said laws; be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That after the first day of February next, the said several recited acts, and all matters and things therein contained, be, and they are hereby repealed, and rendered null and void to all intents and purposes whatsoever.

II. And in order to encourage the fiflicries of this kingdom by equal bounties as are given in Great Britain, and to provide a nursery of fcamcn for the navy of the empire; be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That a bounty of thirty shillings per ton, shall be paid annually out of his Majesty's revenues, under the management of the commissioners of the revenue, to the owner orowuers of such vesselor vessels residing in this kingdom, or their agents

and if but of'twenty tons burthen, manned with four men on board, for the first twenty tons, and one additional man for every eight tons, by which the said vessel shall exceed twenty'tons burden, and if entered for the herring fishery, shall have also on board two barrels or (laves, and hoops to make two barrels for every ton burden which said vessel shall measure; and if fitted out for the'white fishery, shall have on board one boulter or long line, sufficiently equipped with not less than three: hundred hooks, and also two hand-lines for each man on board said vessel, and also one line through one bait-bulket, two splitting-knives, anti thiee calks for the saving of blubber or oil, and also one hundred spare hooks for each man on board, and shall also have four ton of salt on board for the first twenty tons, and one additional ton of salt for every fix tons which such vessel shall measure above twenty tons, nor unless such vessel shall have been registered with the collector or other chief officer of the port to which llie belongs, if for the summer fishery, on or before the twenty fifth day of April, and if for the winter 'fishery on or before the twenty fifth day of October, and shall proceed to some one of the places of general rendezvous herein after appointed, being first visited and measured in the presence of the collector, or in his absence, of the port-surveyor, by an officer or officers of the revenue belonging to such port, appointed by the commissioners of his Majesty's revenue, or any three or more of them for the purpose, who shall take an account of the tonnage thereof by admeasurement in the mode prescribed as to vessels respecting tobacco, and shall certify upon oath before the collector of the district, or before a fub-commissioner of his Majesty's revenue, who are hereby empowered to administer the same, such his or their visitation, examination, and admeasurement to the commissioners of his Majesty's revenue as follows, viz.

XXV. And whereas it would greatly facilitate the trade to the West Indies, and be a mutual advantage to the British and Irish fisheries, if a reciprocal liberty was granted to (lore such herrings, as are deltined for re-exportation: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That so soon as permission shall be granted by the laws of Great Britain, for the entry of Irish herrings, duty free, to be llored for re-exportation, that all British caught fish entered from Great Britain, shall be admitted duty free, provided bond shall be given to the collector, that the same shall not be consumed in this kingdom, in like manner as for other commodities entered for re-exportation.

XXVI. and if it shall appear to such inspector or inspectors, by the testimony upon oath of such informer, or other witness or witnesses, that the person or persons so informed against, or complained of, shall have been guilty of the offence or offences with which such person or persons shall have been so charged, then, and in every such case, such person or persons so appointed to inspefl as aforesaid, shall by warrant under his or their hand and seal, cause all and every the fine or fines to which said offender or offenders is, or are, or shall be liable to, be levied by distress and sale of the goods of such offender, and for want of such distress or payment, to levy such distress upon the vessel or boat to which such offender belongs; and if the person or persons so complained against shall abscond, then the master or owner of such vessel, or the skipper of such boat shall appear before said inspector within twenty four hours after the service of notice to appear before him; and if such master, owner, or skipper shall not sufficiently exculpate himself by affidavit from being accessary to the absconding of such person or persons in that case upon representation of the inspector to the commissioners of his Majesty's revenue, such master, owner, or skipper, shall forfeit twenty pounds, and the person so absconding, shall be for ever debarred from recovering any wages or share of fish, to which he would have been otherwise entitled, by reason of his being an hand, or one of the crew on board such vessel, as also all bounties to which he would otherwise have been entitled.

CHAP. XLI.

An Act for amending an Act, entitled, An Act for the ijfu'ing Treasury Bills to the Amount therein mentioned,i for the Purpose of promoting Manufactures, by providing for the Settlement of a Number of ininjlrious Manufacturers at Prosperous in the County of Kildare, and for other Purposes.

WHEREAS by an act passed in the twenty third and twenty fourth years of His Majesty's reign, entitled,' An act jbr the issuing treasury hills to the amount therein mentiettedy for the purpose of promoting manufactures, by providing for the settlement of a number of industrious manufacturers at Prosperous in the county of Kildare, it was enacted, in order to enable Robert Brooke of Prosperous aforesaid, esquire, to employ the manufacturers therein mentioned, lately settled, and such as thereafter might be and employed at said town of Prosperous, that his Majesty's vice treasurer or vice treasurers, receiver or paymaster general, his or their deputy or deputies should, at the request of the said Robert Brooke, issue treasury bills in manner therein mentioned, for any sum or sums, not exceeding in the whole the sum of twenty live thousand pounds, to bear such rate of imereft, and to be payable at such time as in the said act specified: and whereas it was by the said act provided, that no such treasury bills should be issued or delivered, unless the said Robert Brooke by him-fclf, or with a fufliciem furcty or sureties, should have given security by recognizance, or otherwise conditioned to pay into his Majesty's treasury, at the times therein mentioned, a sum equal to the half yearly interest of the said sum of twenty five thousand pounds, and also the said sum of twenty five thousand pounds, and further conditioned as in the said act is mentioned: and whereas the said Robert Brooke having applied to the said vice treasurer, or his deputy, to issue treasury bills to the amount of the said twenty five thousand pounds, the said Robert Brooke, in order to authorize the issuing of the fame, acknowledged before the lord chief baron of his Majesty's court of exchequer a recognizance to his Majesty, for the sum of fifty thousand pounds, conditioned as in the said receited act is appointed, whereupon treasury bills to the amount of the said sum of twenty five thousand pounds were issued: and whereas pursuant to his Majesty's letter under his sign manual, bearing date the tenth day of September, one thousand seven hundred and eighty four, directed to his grace the lord lieutenant of this kingdom; a sum of seven thousand pounds was issued from the treasury of this kingdom, and advanced and lent to the said Robert Brooke, the better to enable him to carry on the manufacturcsestablished at Prosperous aforesaid, and to retain the ma-nufafturers employed therein; and in order to secure the repayment thereof, the said Robert Brook, on the twenty third day of September last, acknowledged before one of the barons of the said court of exchequer, a recognizance to his Majesty for the sum of seven thousand pounds, conditioned for the repayment of the said sum at the time therein mentioned: and whereas said manufacture is now in a flourishing condition, and the continuing of and carrying on of the same to the considerable extent in which it is now carried on by the said Robert Brooke,

and

The twenty fifth Year of George III. 281

and the establishing thereof arc of great national importance, but by reason of the nature and effect of the said recognizances, the said Robert Brooke is deprived of the credit and confidence necessary in commercial dealings, and is thereby the less able to carry on the said manufacture in so extensive and satisfacto'ry a manner as otherwise he might: and whereas the value of the property of the said Robert Brooke hath since his receiving the said treasury bills to the amount of the said sum of twenty five thousand pounds, been considerably encreased, by his having compleated the erecting of the aforesaid town of Prosperous, and the several buildings and factories used for carrying on the said manufacture, which town hath been so built and erected upon pan of the lands of Curry Hills in the county of Kildare, containing three hundred and forty seven acres, one rood and nine perches, at an expence exceeding the said sums of twenty five thousand pounds, which lauds the said Robert Brooke holds, by virtue of a lease for lives, renewable for ever, for which he paid a considerable sum by way of fine: and whereas it is deemed reasonable that the person of the said Robert Brooke, and likewise his lands and goods, (other than such as in manner herein after mentioned, shall be deemed sufficient security for the sums of twenty five thousand pounds, and seven thousand pounds) be released and exonerated from the said recognizance, in order that the said Robert Brooke may thereby be the better enabled to carry on the said manufacture to that extent, and with that degree of credit, which an undertaking proraifing such national advantages-requires: wherefore be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords Spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after such time as his Majesty's court of exchequer in Ireland shall have signified, that the approbation of his Majesty's attorney general under his hand, of the title of the said Robert Brooke, to any part or parts of the estates or property of the said Robert Brooke, to be specified by the said court of exchequer, had been laid before them, and the said court of exchequer shall approve of the said part or parts of the said estates or property, as sufficient security for the said sums of twenty five thousand pounds, and seven thousand pounds, or for either of them, the person of the said Robert Brooke, and likewise all and singular his lands and goods, other than such as shall be so specified by the said court of exchequer as aforesaid, shall be, and the same are hereby absolutely relcafcti, exonerated, and discharged of and from the said recognizances, or such one of them, as the said court of exchequer shall ascertain the security, so to be specified-by them, to be sufficient for such approbation, to be filed of record in the chief -remembrancer's office of his Majesty's said court of exchequer.

II. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this act shall be deemed, and taken, and allowed in all courts within this kingdom, as a publick act, and all judges are hereby required as such to take notice thereof, without (pccialiy pleading die.fame.

XXIX. And whereas the laws now in being have been found insufficient to prevent the publick fountains or conduits in the city of Dublin from being destroyed or damaged by evil disposed persons: for remedy whereof, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any publick fountain or conduit shall be destroyed or damaged between the felting and riling of the fun, the costs and charges of reinstating or repairing the fame, shall be paid by the church-wardens of the parish wherein such fountain or conduit hath been, or shall he erected, unless they shall apprehend and prosecute to conviction, in the manner prescribed by the act passed in the twenty third and twenty fourth years of his present Majesty's reign, for the more effectually paving, cleansing, and lighting the streets of the city of Dublin, the person or persons who destroyed or damaged such fountain or conduit, or unless they shall> prove that such damage or injury was done or committed between sun-rise and sun-set; which said costs and charges shall be paid and recovered as by the said act is directed.

And whereas it may be very inconvenient to bring prisoners up to any of his Majesty's courts of record in Dublin, from country prisons at a distance from Dublin, by reason of the difficulties and expences attending the fame.: for remedy whereof be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twentieth day of May, one thousand seven hundred and eighty live, all and every prisoner and prisoners, who were on the aforesaid first day of January, one thousand seven hundred and eighty five, in actual custody for debt in any gaol or prison of this kingdom, other than the gaols or prisons within the city and county of the city of Dublin, and -who have been continued ever since in such custody, shall and may petition the court of law out of or under which the process issued, upon which he, she, or they were and shall be so imprisoned, in like manner as prisoners in general are herein before enabled or authorized to do and all and every such prisoner and prisoners so petitioning, shall annex to his, her, or their petition, a schedule, setting forth and containing a full account of his, her, or their whole real and personal estate, interests, and benefits, in like manner as is herein before preferred, as to such prisoners as aforesaid, first giving notice to the several creditors at whose suit he, she, or they Hand charged or imprisoned, and also giving notice in the Dublin Gazette, to all his, her, or their other creditors, of such intention to petition, in like manner as is before directed, respecting prisoners seeking their discharge under this act; and upon every such petition and schedule being so presented to such court as aforesaid, the said court shall make a rule to cause the prisoner or prisoners to be brought at an expence not exceeding four pence per mile, to be paid as herein after mentioned, to the next assizes to be holden for the county or place where he or she shall be imprisoned. Inch expence as aforesaid to be paid by such prisoner, if able to pay the same, or if unable, and such inability be made out to the satisfaction of the judge before whom such prisoner or prisoners shall be brought, then to be paid by the treasurer of the county; and the grand jury of said county are hereby empowered to make a presentment for the fame, upon a certificate under the hand of said judge certifying such inability; and the several creditors at whose suit such prisoners shall stand charged, shall be served with a copy of such rule, and of such petition and schedule, or the same shall be left with his, her, or their attorney or attornies, or at his, her, or their dwelling house, or usual place of abode, ten days at the lea ft before such assizes 5 and it shall be lawful for 3 tk

XXXIV. Provided always nevertheless, That all conveyances, assignments, and incumbrances made by such prisoner with a fraudulent purpose, to conceal or secrete his or her estate or effects, or whereby his or her creditors may be defrauded or hindered of their just debts, shall be absolutely null and void, and the assignee or trustee in whom the estate and effects of such prisoner, according to the meaning and intent of this act, would otherwise be, shall be absolutely seized and possessed thereof, and be entitled thereto, and may fell, convey, and dispose thereof, notwithstanding any such conveyance, assignment, or incumbrance, as if none such was made, Cave only that if it shall appear that any sum or sums of money shall have really and bona fide been paid, advanced for, or on the fame, then the person or persons so having paid and advanced, shall have, a lien on such estate and effects for so much as shall have been so actually and bona fide paid and advanced, with interest for the fame, and for no more.

XXXVI. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in case any person or persons hath or have accepted of any trust or trusts under any conveyance, assignment or otherwise, as to any part of the estates and effects of any prisoner voluntarily seeking his or her discharge, under this act, or against whom such compulsory course or proceedings shall be had or pursued as aforesaid, whereby any part of such estates or effects shall be concealed from the assignee or trustee thereof, and shall knowingly conceal the fame, or shall wilfully neglect to discover the same to such assignee or trustee respectively, every such person and persons shall forfeit the sum of one hundred pounds, and double the value of the estate and effects covered by such trust, or concealed by him or her, to be recovered by action of debt, bill, plaint, or information in any of his Majesty's courts of record in Dublin, together with double costs.

XXXVIII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the foregoing provision as to a compulsory proceeding against prisoners for debt in any gaol or prison within the city and county of the city of Dublin, and the county of Dublin, shall extend to all prisoners for debt, who were or have been such prisoners at and for the times before mentioned in that respect, in any other gaol of this kingdom, in case such prisoners, or any of them, shall be removed by due course of law from such other gaol or prison into any such gaol or prison within the city or county of the city of Dublin, or county of Dublin.

CHAP. XLVII.

An Act for amending the several Laws relating to the registering of Wills and Deeds In the Registry Office of this Kingdom, and for the better regulating and conducing the Business of the said Office.

WHEREAS the registry of deeds, pursuant to an act of <!iH queen Parliament passed in this kingdom in the sixth year of the "ne' c. 2‘ reign of her late Majesty queen Anne, entitled, An act for the publick registering of all deeds, conveyances, and wills that shall be made of any honors, manors, lands, tenements, or hereditaments; and also to another act for amending the same, made in the eighth year of gtj, Anne, her said late Majesty queen Anne, has been found of general and greate-I0-utility; and whereas the hours heretofore appointed by the said first receited act, for the attendance of the register or his deputy, are since found to be very inconvenient to the publick; be it therefore enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the twenty fourth day of June next, so much of a clause in the said first receited act, which requires hours of at-the attendance of the said register or his deputy, between the hours of nine and twelve in the forenoon, and between the hours or deputy re-

XVII. And whereas cases may happen wherein the regulating the price of labour, particularly in the hosiery branch, may not only be expedient but necessary: be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful for the trustees aforesaid, or any seven or more of them, at any time during the continuance of this act, to summon before them any person or persons concerned in any of the manufactures specified in this act, and to examine upon oath (which oath any one of them is hereby empowered to administer) into the rates of labour, and prices of workmanship thereof, and into the real value of such labour and workmanship, and to ascertain and direct such rates and prices as to them shall seem proper to be taken in any part or parts of this kingdom; and if any person shall, after the fame be thrice published in the Dublin Gazette, take, demand, or pay in any part or parts of the kingdom specified in such publication for any labour or workmanship, any higher rate or price than what shall be so ascertained for the fame, or shall by gift or otherwise encrease the price of workmanship beyond such rate, every person so offending shall for every offence, forfeit the sum of twenty pounds, to be recovered and applied in manner herein after mentioned, and every such person shall be disqualified from receiving any bounty from the said trustees, or any part or share of any of the sums granted by this act.

XVIII. And for the relief of all such persons as may have been guilty of any unlawful combinations, or acts described as evidence of unlawful combination by an act passed in the nineteenth and twentieth years of his present Majesty, entitled. An act to prevent combinations, and for the further encouragement of trade, and who repent and are willing to all conformable to law for the future: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful for every person, who has at any time previous to the twenty fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty five, entered into or acceded to any combination contrary- to the said last mentioned act, or to any other act or acts of Parliament, or into any illegal agreement to force others to accede to any such combination, or to any illegal agreement, or who shall have illegally administered to any person, threatened by letter or otherwise, or

forced

XXI. And whereas that species of bay yarn, commonly called breech bay yarn, has been made use of for the weft of certain species of worsted goods, to the great discredit of the manufacture: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons shall make use of an breech bay yarn in any camblet, lading, fattinet, crape, or double duff, such person or persons shall for every such offence forfeit the sum of ten pounds.

XXII. And whereas the sum of fifteen thousand pounds granted last session of Parliament to certain trustees, to be paid in bounties on woollen and other manufactures, was applied in paying bounties accordingly, and many persons not apprized of the time when the said sum was exhausted, continued to fell or purchase, on expectation’of the said bounty, and claimed it accordingly: be it enacted, That it shall and may he lawful for the said trustees to pay, if they shall think proper, out of the said sum of twenty thousand pounds, the bounties so claimed or in lieu thereof, such smaller bounties as they ftial! think proper.

XXIII. And be it further enacted, That no wheel, reel, loom, spinning jenny, carding machine, or implement of manufacture given, lent, or distributed by the said trustees, and sealed with a ltainp appointed by them, shall be distrained on account of rent, or arrears of rent, or l'eized or sold by virtue of any writ of execution.

XXIV. And be it further enacted, That the said several fume of twenty thousand pounds, five thousand pounds, and four thousand pounds, shall be paid by the vice-treasurers, receivers, or paymaf-ters-general, their deputy or deputies, to the order of any seven or more of the said trustees without any further or other warrant to be had, sued for, or obtained in that behalf.

XXV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all penalties and forfeitures created by this act, shall and may be sued for and recovered by any person in any of his Majesty's courts of law, by civil bill, or by bill, plaint, or information, in which no essoign, protection, or wager at law, nor more than one imparlance shall be allowed; the whole amount thereof to be paid to the person filing for the fame; and that if any fiiit or prosecution shall be commenced or carried on by the direction of the said trustees, it shall be lawful for them to defray the expences thereof out of the said sum of live thousand pounds herein before mentioned.

CHAP. LI.

An Act for preventing Vexatious Injunctions to say Proceedings at Law; and for giving Cofs to Defendants in Courts of Equity, in certain cases.

WHEREAS by means of bills filed in courts of equity to stay proceedings at law, upon frivolous and groundless suggestions, and of injunctions granted thereupon, landlords and other creditors are greatly aggrieved and delayed in the recovery of their rents, and other just demands: for remedy whereof, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, In all injune- and by the authority of the same, That in all injunctions which outoMmy shall issue out of any court of equity, to stay any defendant court of equi* from proceeding at law, except upon good and sufficient equity iiVrcin'diere confessed in the answer of such defendant, there shall be inserted "b»>ro-a provisoe, that such defendant shall be at liberty to call for a plea, and to proceed to trial thereon, and for want of a plea to enter up judgment, but execution to be flayed.

Defendant And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That H litw(Jty1to at t,me ‘"jnnAion shall be issued, the defendant hath tion, not filed any declaration at law, he shall be at liberty to file a de-proeifoe, claration, and to proceed thereupon in manner aforesaid; proas to courts of vyeti that nothing herein contained, shall be construed to re-equity.

strain courts of equity from making any order to stay any defendant from proceeding to trial at law, upon sufficient grounds appearing to them*

Full coda HI. And whereas, when a bill in equity is dismissed by the to defendant plaintiff, or by the defendant, for want of prosecution, the de-rota" ' fendant, in such cases, usually obtains but twenty shillings coils, whereby great encouragement is given to litigious persons to file vexatious and groundless bills: be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in all cases where the plaintiff in equity shall dismiss his own bill, or the defendant shall dismiss the fame for want of prosecution, the plaintiff in such suit shall pay to the defendant his full colls, to be taxed by the master, or other officer of the court.

IV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said book shall he kept by the clerk of the peace among the records of the county, county of a city, or county of a town; and that each entry shall be deemed a record of the county, county of a city, or county of a town; and that the said clerk of the peace be required to preserve the said book without addition or alteration from one court of quarter sessions to another, neither writing in the fame himself, nor permitting any other person to write therein, but that the same shall nevertheless be open to the inspection of any person at any time, between the hours of twelve and two o'clock in the day time when such person shall require it, upon his giving twenty four hours notice, except only on Sundays and the greater feasts, he paying for the same five shillings, and no more, and being debarred the use of pen and ink during the whole of that time j and that if any person having a vote in die same county, county of a city, or county of a town, shall require of the clerk of the peace to furniflt him with a copy of the said registry book, or any part thereof, the said clerk of the peace shall write or cause to be written a true copy of the fame, and within a reasonable time furnish the said person there-with, charging him for the fame at the rate of two pence for every four freeholders foregiftcred, including the index; and that if any person having a vote in the same county, shall require from the clerk of the peace a copy of the index, or any part thereof, the said clerk of the peace shall furnish him therewith within eight days, unit fs the number of freeholders shall exceed four thousand, then within-eight days for every four thousand names in the said registry contained, charging him for the fame, at the rate of one penny for every fix names of freeholders contained in the said copy.

And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That at the final close of the poll, but before the (beriff shall tot up the votes given on each side, the clerk of the peace, and the treasurer shall each of them declare upon oath, to be taken in open court upon the Iloly Evangclifts, (which oath the sheriff is hereby empowered and required to administev) whether any and what alterations (if any) have been made in their respective books, and when and by whom to the bell of their knowledge and belief, except additions made from time to time at the quarter sessions pursuant to the provisions of this act.

IX. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any freeholder shall find that the adUng clerk of the peace has disobeyed this act, by not registering his freehold in the manner hereby directed, and giving to the treasurer a copy of the registry book, in the manner and at the time before mentioned, or by crafing, tearing out, or designedly making the same, or any part thereof illegible, or dc-signedly, or through neglect fullering any person to do so, he flnll forfeit the sum of one hundred pounds, and be difinified from his oilice of clerk of the peace \ and if he shall refuse or neglodt to furnish any freeholder with a copy of the said registry book, or the index thereof, or of any part thereof, as hereby before required, so long as said book shall continue in his custody or power, ami so long ns that part shall neither have been erased, torn out, or deuced j ami provided no circumstance renders it impossible for him at that time to give such copy, the said freeholder shall be entitled to recover for every such offence from the said acting clerk of the peace by civil bill, the sum of twenty pounds, process being served twelve days inclusive before the first day of the assizes.

XI. And in order that any freeholder or freeholders may the more easily recover the aforesaid sum or sums in the manner herein before mentioned: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said acting clerk of the peace, upon the receipt of six pence as aforesaid, shall deliver to the freeholder a certificate on parchment or vellum, signed by the court, and countersigned by him, who is hereby required to sign the fame, of his having been duly registered on that day; which certificate, though no part of the registry, shall, when proved, be sufficient evidence upon any civil bill brought for the penalty aforesaid; and that if upon any election for any county, county of a city, or county of a town, it shall appear to the sheriff or (hcriffs upon oath, (which oath such sheriff or sheriffs is am! are hereby empowered and required to administer) that the registry book to be kept by the clerk of the peace, and the copy thereof to be kept by the trea-furer, as is herein directed, shall have been loft, destroyed, or so defaced, that the affidavits or entries therein shall be illegible, every such certificate shall when proved, be sufficient evidence that the person therein named was duly registered.

XII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person shall (leal, secretc, or destroy, or maliciously alter or deface the said registry book, or affidavit or affidavits, required by this act to be kept by the clerk of the peace of any county, county of a city, or county of a town, and the treasurer’s copy thereof, or either of them, whether in the body of the said books, or their index, the person who shall be convicted of having so offended, shall suffer three years imprisonment.

XIII. Provided always, That nothing herein contained shall prevent any person from giving his vote at any election, whose freehold shall conlift of some benefice in the church, or in some office to which a freehold of forty shillings at the lead is or shall have been annexed: provided also, That no person shall be precluded from giving his vote at such election, as not being duly registered, whose freehold or rent-charge shall have come to him by marriage, marriage-settlement, defeent, limitation, or devise, within six months before the test of the writ to the sheriff for holding such election; provided he shall have duly registered the fame at any time before the test of the writ for holding such election, if any quarter sessions shall have been held there between the time such freehold came, and the test of the writ to the sheriff aforesaid.

XVI. And whereas doubts have arisen whether freeholders who have not themselves been registered, have a right to vote as being in possession of freeholds which had been formerly registered by the person then in possession thereof; be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no freeholder shall vote at any election of members to serve in Parliament, who shall not have been Tcgiftered in the manner hitherto used before the first day of June next, or who shall not have been registered in such manner and in such cases as prescribed by this act.

XVII. XIX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person shall, from and after the passing of this act, unlawfully detain or refuse to deliver up said. books, or either of them, in manner and at the times herein directed, such person so offending, shall forfeit the sum of ten pounds sterling, for every day he shall so unlawfully detain the fame, to be recovered by civil bill before the judges of assize in any county where such olfence shall be committed, and shall also upon conviction of such offence before the judges of assize in any county where such offence shall be committed, suffer one month's imprisonment for every day he shall so unlawfully detain the same.

XX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the church-wardens in such parishes as aforesaid, from and after the passing of this act, in case of any neglect or refusal to comply with the several matters and things required of them by said first mentioned act, shall forfeit for every such offence the sum of one hundred pounds sterling, to be recovered by any person who shall sue for the same in any of his Majesty's courts of record.

XXI. Provided always, and be it declared and enacted by the authority aforr-said, That no affidavit or affirmation to be made pursuant to this or any other act for registering freeholders, shall be deemed to require any stamp, or be liable to any duty payable to the crown.

XXII. Provided always, That nothing herein contained, shall affect any election that shall be held in and for any county, county of a city, or county of a town, before the first day of January, one thousand seven hundred and eighty fix.

XXIII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all and every person and persons who shall falsely and wilfully swear or affirm, contrary to the true intent and meaning of this act, being thereof indtded and convicted, shall suffer such pains, penalties, and disabilities, as persons convicted of wilful and corrupt perjury ought by law to suffer; and that any person claiming to be a freeholder, who shall be guilty of perjury in registering a freehold of forty shillings at the least, or a rent charge, without being Tcally and bona fide possessed of such freehold orrent charge, and shall be thereof convicted and condemned, and shall have suffered the pains and penalties thereof, shall, upon due proof thereof, before the sheriff in open court, be for ever incapable of giving any vote at any election of a

CHAP. LIII.

An Act to amend an Act, entitled, An Act for the more speedy and effectual recovery of the King's Debts.

WHEREAS by an act passed in the twenty first and 21 & 2, twenty second years of his Majesty's reign, entitled, An Geo. 3. c. 2. aS for the more speedy and effectual recovery of the King's debts; divers provisions have been made to enable his Majesty, his heirs and successors, more speedily and effectually to recover debts due to his Majesty, his heirs and successors, or to his royal predecessors, by collectors of the revenue, and other publick accountants: and whereas the several provisions contained in the said act, have been found not to be fuffidently effectual: and whereas great difficulties and Losses have been occasioned to his Majesty, and his royal predecessors, by reason of the number of persons necessary, or supposed to be necessary to be warned in all cases where any writ of feire facias hath heretofore issued, to warn the heir and ter-tenants of any debtor of his Majesty, or his royal predecessors: for the prevention whereof, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the twenty fourth day of June next, when

Au A3 to prevent the Exportation of Hay from this Kingdom for a limited Time.

H EREA 8 from the present appearances throughout tins kingdom, a

very great scarcity of hay is apprehended: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with die advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That if any person shall, after the second day of August, one thousand seven hundred and eighty five, and before the twenty fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty fix, export any hay, or ship on board any vessel any hay, with an intent to export the fame, except such quantity as may be necessary for the provision of cattle which may be exported on board such ship or vessel, and for which a licence expressing the quantity shall be granted by the officer of the port to be appointed by the commissioners of his Majesty's revenue for the purpose, the person so offending, shall forfeit for every ton of hay so shipped or exported, the sum of twenty pounds, to be recovered by action of debt, or information, by any person who shall sue for the same in any of his Majesty's four courts at Dublin, in which no essoign, or wager of law, shall be allowed.

An Act to explain and amend an Act pajfied in the twenty-third and twenty-fourth Years of his present Majesty, entitled, An Act for ascertaining the Qualifications of such Persons as shall take out Commifions of the Peace for the Counties at large.

WHEREAS by an act passed in the twenty-third and twenty-fourth years of his present Majesty, entitled, An act for ascertaining the Qualifications of such persons as shall take out commissions of the peace for counties at large, it is amongst other things provided and enacted, That the said act, or any thing therein contained, shall not extend, or be construed to extend to any city or town being a county of itself, or to any other city, town, or liberty, having justices of the peace within their respective limits and precincts, by charter, commission, or otherwise, but that in every such city, town, liberty, and place, such persons may be capable to be justices of the peace, and in such manner only as they might have been if said act had never been made, any thing therein contained to the contrary thereof, in any wise notwithstanding: and whereas doubts have arisen under the said receited act, whether justices of the peace, who by virtue of such charters are justices of the peace not only of their respective cities, towns, liberties, and places, but also for counties at large, are entitled or qualified to act as justices of the peace for such counties at large, without having such qualifications or estate as in the said receited act is particularly mentioned and required: and whereas it would tend much to the hinderance and delay of justice, if such charter justices could not aft as justices of the peace within such counties at large, without having such qualifications or estate as aforesaid: be it therefore enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords l'piritual and temporal,'and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That nothing in the said-receited act; contained, shall be construed, deemed, or taken in any manner whatsoever, to prevent or hinder any such justice of the peace, who by charter, commission, or otherwise, as aforesaid, is a justice of the peace for any county at large, from acting as such in such county at large, notwithstanding he may not have such qualification or estate as by the said receited act is required, but that such charter justices may be capable to act and be justices of the peace for fhch counties at large, in such manner only as they might have been

XXI. And whereas in case of sickness or necessary absence, the paymaster of corn premiums is empowered at present by law to appoint a deputy to execute the duties of said office: and whereas in such calc, such deputy so appointed, may through some fatality be disabled from attending said office: and whereas from the considerable hurry of business in said office, particularly on market-days, it might prove expedient, and the means of preventing and detecting of frauds, and of expediting the business of said office, if the paymaster had the assistance of one or two deputies on all occasions; be it therefore enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the paymaster of corn premiums shall and may in all cases have power, and is hereby empowered to appoint and remove, during his plealurc, from time to time, one or two persons, as his deputy or deputies, for whom he shall be answerable, blit who shall be first approved of by the commissioners of excise, or any three of them, and shall be paid at the expence of the said paymaster, and each of said deputies shall have like power of administering oaths, and executing the duties of said office as the principal.

XVII. XVIII. Provided always, That when and so soon as one or more wharf or wharfs shall be erected for the saving and storing ballad pursuant to the powers herein after contained, and that there shall be a sufficient quantity of ballad in and upon such wharf or wharfs for the supplying of any ship or vessel wanting the fame, it shall and may be lawful to and for the said corporation, or the officer or officers to be appointed by them for that purpose, to order and direct at their discretion any ship or vessel requiring ballad as aforesaid, save only and except such- ships or vessels as shall have discharged their cargoes below such of the said wharfs as shall be situated the furthed down in the said harbour, to go along-fide of such wharf or wharfs, and take in such ballad from the fide or fides thereof, in which case the said corporation or their officer or officers shall not be obliged to furnish such ship or vessel with ballad in a lighter or lighters.

XIX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid^' That the said corporation shall furnish or cause to be furnished at the rate herein after mentioned, to the commanders or masters of any ships or vessels which shall from time to time arrive within the said port, laden with ballad, good and sufficient lighters or gabbards, with proper and sufficient workmen and tools for the taking and carrying such ballad from such ships or vessels within twenty four hours after notice for that purpose shall be given by such commanders or masters respectively at the aforesaid office, if wind and weather shall permit, and in case wind and weather shall not then permit the fame, then within twelve hours after wind and weather shall permit them so to do.

XXI. And to the end that such lighters or gabbards as shall or may be employed in bringing ballast to, and taking ballast from such ships or vessels as aforesaid respectively, shall not be longer detained in so doing than shall be necessary; be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in case the crew of any ffiip or vessel shall neglect or refuse to take in or call out their ballast, so as to occasion any unreafo nable or unnecessary delay therein, to any lighter or lighters, gabbard or gabbards which may be employed under the said corporation to bring ballast to, or take ballast from such ffiip or vessel, that then, and in such case, the commander or master of every ffiip or vessel respectively so delaying, shall pay, or cause to be paid to the ballast-master for the time being, for the damage which shall be sustained by such delay, such sum or sums as the said corporation shall, in a summary manner, finally adjudge and determine; such fuin and sums of money to be levied by warrant under the seal of the said. corporation, by falc of the offenders goods: provided such sum do in no case exceed twelve pence for every hour such lighter or gabbard shall be so unnecessarily detained by the neglect or default of the crew of such ship or ships, vessel or vessels as aforesaid.

XXII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if the master or commander of any ffiip or vessel which shall be in the said harbour, shall take or permit, or suffer to be taken into such ffiip or vessel, any ballast whatsoever from any person or persons, save only from such person or persons as shall be thereunto appointed by the said corporation, or shall permit or suffer any ballast whatsoever, to be taken from such ship or vessel, save only by such person or persons as shall be thereunto appointed as aforesaid; then, not only said master or commander, but also the person who shall deliver to, or take from such ffiip or vessel, such ballast as aforesaid, shall, for every such offence, forfeit the sum of five pounds sterling, to be paid to such person or persons as shall give information of such offence to the said corporation.

XXXIV. And to the intent that no ashes, dirt, or filth may for the future be call into the said harbour, or into any fewer or stream which empties itself into the said harbour: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That every person or persons who shall call any ashes, dirt, filth, or rubbish into the said harbour, or into any fewer or ft team that empties itself therein, being in a summary way' thereof convicted upon oath before the chief magistrate of the said town of Belfast, or before any one or more of the justices of the peace of the county of Antrim, of any of the crimes aforesaid, committed within their respective authorities, shall forfeit for each and every such offence the film of five shillings, for the benefit and advantage of every such person And persons 'as shall and will discover and prosecute for the fame, which said sum of five shillings shall and may be levied by distress and sale of the goods and chattles of the offenders, by the warrant of the said chief magistrate or the justice of the peace before whom the party shall be convicted; and in case such offender or offenders shall not have wherewithal to satisfy the sum of five /hillings, that then and in that case it shall and may be lawful to and for the said chief magistrate or justice of the peace respectively to fend the said offender or offenders to the house of correlation or common gaol of the said county, to be kept to hard labour, so as the confinement of the said offenders may not for any one offence exceed the number of five days.

XXXV. And for the more effectual cleaning of the said harbour: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all ballad that shall from thenceforth be put on board any ship or vessel within the said harbour, pursuant to the directions of this act, shall be taken out of such part or parts only of the said harbour, as shall from time to time be directed by the officer or officers, to be appointed by the said corporation for that purpose, and that no ballad shall be carried from one ship to supply another, and that no ballad shall be thrown out of any ship into the said port or river, upon pain of forfeiting for every of the said offences the sum of five pounds, to be recovered and levied as herein after directed, one half to be paid to the person who shall give information thereof, and the other to the said corporation.

An Act for rai/ing the Sum of Twenty Thousand Pounds upon the Manors of Port Dungloe and Mount Charles, in the County of Donegal, the Estate of the Right Honourable William Conyng-ham, to be expended, together with another Sum of Twenty Thottfand Pounds granted by Parliament, in promoting the Fi/h-eries on the Western Coast of the County of Donegal, in Manner therein mentioned.

WHEREAS the encouragement of the fisheries of Ireland would highly tend to promote the wealth and population of the kingdom, and would greatly increase the naval power of the empire: and whereas a petition hath been presented to the house of commons by the said right honourable William Conyngham, setting forth, " that great shoals of herrings, cod,

" ling, and hake annually resort to the islands of Arran and the petition " Roffes, on the coast of the county Donegal, where near three nouralile " hundred vessels have usually assembled every year for many " years past for the purpose of curing the fish: that {hoals of herrings make their appearance in the greatest quantities during the " winter months, and enter the several small hays and inlets which " renders it necessary to carry on the fishery by small boats: that " for want of a proper establishment of refineries of (alt, and " llores to deposit foreign salt, for want of convenient buildings " to cure the fish, and coopers to prepare calks, no opportunity " offers of curing the fish that resort thither at other seasons " than in the months of November, December, and January, when " the vessels on bounty attend for that purpose: that the neighbouring country is little cultivated, and the houses of the inhabitants " insufficient to give {belter to the merchants: that the failure of " the British fishery (on which five hundred thousand pounds has " been expended) is acknowledged to have been owing to the neglect of making a proper establishment for the reception of persons " employed in that trade contiguous to the feat of the fishery, ami " without which it seems obvious, that in this kingdom this " great national source of wealth and strength can never be " brought to any great publick benefit: that the petitioner had " already incurred a very considerable expence in promoting this Vol. XIII. 5 Q. III. And be it enacted, That every maltster, or other maker of malt, shall within four months after he or she shall make, or ought to have made such monthly return as aforesaid, pay and-clear off all such duties as'shall be due from him, her or them respectively, for and on account of all such malt as aforesaid by him, her, or them made, unless such malt shall be sooner removed from the malt-house or place where the same shall have been made, in which case the said duties shall be paid for all such malt as shall be intended to be removed before any-permit for removing, carrying, or conveying the same shall be granted.

IV. And be it further enacted, That every maltster or other person chargeable with the duties aforesaid, who shall neglect or refuse to make such return and payment respectively as aforesaid, shall forfeit and lose for every such offence respectively the sum of fifty pounds \ and that no such maltster or other person, after default made, shall deliver or carry out any malt until he or she shall have paid and cleared of T the duty as aforesaid, on pain of forfeiting double the value of such malt so delivered and carried out; any thing herein contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

V. And be it enacted and declared, That twelve (tones of malt shall be deemed and takeu to be a barrel within the true intent and meaning of this act unless wherein otherwise expressed and declared in the fame; any law or statute to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding.

VI. And be it enacted, That as often as any difference-or dispute shall arise be-

tween the person or persons making malt, or having malt in his, her, or their possession as aforesaid; and the gauger or other officer of the revenue respecting the amount of the charge made as aforesaid, the return or report so made shall be vert' fied by the oath of such gauger or other officer to be made before one of the chief commissioners or fub-commissioners of excise of the proper dillrid who are hereby respectively authorized to administer the same, that the said return or report so by him made was truly and fairly made to the best of his (kill and knowledge, and the said return or report shall then be a charge upon the person or persons making malt, or having malt in his, her, or their possession fodifputing the fame, and not otherwise.

VII. Provided always, That no person or persons shall be at liberty to dispute any charge made by such gauger or other officer, nor shall it be necessary for such gauger or other officer to verify such charge by affidavit, unless such person or persons shall have made such return as aforesaid of the malt made by him, her, or them, or in his, her, or their possession, within the time herein for that purpose mentioned.

VIII. And be it further enacted, That all malt in the custody of any maker of malt, shall be subject to and chargeable with all and Angular the duties upon malt which may be in arrear and owing by any person or persons for any malt which may have been made by such maltster, or within such mak-house, and shall also be subject to all penalties and forfeitures incurred by the person or persons using such mnlt-house for any offence against this act; and that it shall be lawful in all cases to levy all debts and penalties incurred under and by virtue of this act, and to use such proceedings against such malt as it may be lawful to do in case the debtor or offender was the true and real owner of the fame malt.

XI. XIII. And be it enacted, That every four bushels of such corn or grain making into malt, taken by the gauge as aforesaid, shall be deemed and taken to be equal to a barrel of malt, for the purpose of charging and levying the duties imposed by this act; and that every four bushels of such corn or grain making into malt as aforesaid, shall be subject to the said duty of two shillings and six pence, such bushel to be computed according to the bushel known by the name of the Winchester bushel, containing eight gallons of two hundred and seventy two cubical inches and a quarter each.

CHAP. V.

An Act for regulating the Sugar Trade, and for granting to His Majesty, His Heirs and Successors, the Duties therein mentioned.

WE your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal subjects the commons of Ireland Expiredt$ in Parliament assembled, as a further supply to your Majesty to sup- 1/87* port the expence of your Majesty's government, and with a grateful sense of the great benefits to arise from an open and direct commercial intercourse with the sugar colonies of Great Britain, do most humbly beseech your Majesty, and be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the twenty fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty fix, until the twenty fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty seven inclusive, and no longer, there shall be raised, levied, collected, and paid unto your Majesty, your heirs and successors, for and upon all sugars, the growth, product or manufacture of the British plantations in America, or the West Indies, which shall be imported into this kingdom during the time aforesaid, the several duties, in the schedule marked, No. r. hereunto annexed, which schedule shall be deemed and taken to be to all intents and purposes a part of this act, to be computed upon every hundred weight, containing one hundred and twelve futtlc pounds of such sugars respectively, and so in proportion for any greater orl efs quantity.

II. Provided always, and be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said several duties in the said annexed schedule mentioned, shall be in lieu and full satisfaction of all customs, subsidies, and duties whatsoever, payable upon all such sugars, by virtue of any law or laws heretofore made in this kingdom, and shall be severally paid dowu in ready money net, without any discount or allowance whatsoever.

III. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all such duties, so to be paid upon the importation of all sugars of the growth, produce, or manufacture of the British plantations in America or the West Indies, shall be fully Vol. XIII. 6 G drawn

And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty fix, until the twenty fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty seven inclusive, and no longer, there shall be raised, levied, collected and paid to your Majesty, your heirs and successors, for and upon all refined sugars in loaves, not being bafhrds, and all candy which shall be imported into this kingdom from Great Britain, during the time aforesaid, being of the manufacture of Great Britain, a duty after the rate of one pound sixteen findings and nine pence halfpenny for every one hundred weight, containing one hundred and twelve futtle pounds of such sugars, and so in proportion for any greater or less quantity; and for and upon all refined sugars called bastards, and all ground and powdered refined sugars, and all refined loaf sugar broken in pieces which shall be imported from Great Britain, during the time aforesaid, a duty after the rate of eighteen shillings and eleven pence sixteen twentieths of a penny, and ten fifteenths of a twentieth, for every hundred weight

IX. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That to encourage the refining of sugars in Ireland, the following bounties shall be allowed and paid upon all sugars which shall be refined in this kingdom, and exported from thence during the time aforesaid, that is to say, a bounty after the rate of one pound eight shillings and two pence for every one hundred weight of such sugars containing one hundred and twelve futtle pounds, which shall be exported in the loaf complete and whole, being net, that is to say, of one uniform whiteness throughout, and which shall have gone through the operation of two or more clays since it was last in the pan, and shall have been properly and thoroughly dried in the (love, according to the present practice of refining; and a bounty after the rate of twelve shillings and seven pence, thirteen twentieths of a penny, and five fifteenths of a twentieth, for every one hundred weight, containing one hundred and twelve futtle pounds of such refined sugar called bastard, and of all ground powdered refined sugar, and all refined loaf sugar broken in pieces, the said sugar having been twice clayed and properly dried in the Hove, and of all candy properly refined and manufactured, and freed 'from dirt and feum, which shall be exported during the time aforesaid.

X. Provided always, That if any of the said refined sugars, being in either great or small loaves, commonly called lumps, shall have gone through the operation of three clays at the least since they were last in the pan, and shall be net, and shall have been thoroughly dried in the Hove in the manner herein before directed, though such loaves be exported without the small euds or tips, they shall be deemed complete and whole within the true intent and meaning of this act, and the exporter or exporters of the same shall receive the drawback or bounty accordingly.

An Act for regulating and extending the Tobacco Trade, and for granting to His Majesty, His Heirs and Successors, the Duties therein mentioned

WE your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal subjects the commons of Ireland Expired.

in Parliament assembled, as a further supply to your Majesty to sup- areb port the expences of your Majesty's government, do most humbly beseech your Majesty; and be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the twenty fifth dr.v of March one thousand seven hundred and eighty fix, until the twenty fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty seven inclusive, and no longer, there shall be raised, le-vi d . ollefted, and paid unto your Majesty, your heirs and successors, the fe-m 1 1 ;e5 anu duties herein alter mentioned; that is to say, for and upon all v/bi'Ji shall be imported into this kingdom during the time aforesaid, a duty ilt.r the rate of ten pence per pound weight without any discount or allowance whatsoever.

II. And whereas it may tend much to the encouragement of the tobacco trade, if the importers of tobacco shall be allowed to lodge the fame in ware-houses, and to have time for the payment of the duty thereon: therefore, be it enacted, That every importer of tobacco, if he or she does not choose to pay down the duty as aforesaid, shall and may in lieu of paying down the fame, secure a duty after the rate of eleven pence for each pound weight thereof, in manner following; that is to say, he or (be shall give bond for the amount of such duty, after the rate of eleven pence per pound, to be made payable at the end of fifteen months, to commence at the end of thirty days after the mailer’s report of the ship in which such tobacco shall be Imported.

III. Provided always, That every importer of tobacco who shall land tobacco on bill of view, shall within ten working days after the landing of his or her tobacco, make entry thereof, end pay the duty for the fame, or enter into bond for the payment thereof in manner herein directed, and in failure thereof, every such importer shall forfeit and pay the sum of five pounds for every hogshead of such tobacco which shall not be entered, and for which the duty shall not have been paid or secured as aforesaid, over and above the duties payable on such tobacco.

IV. And be it further enacted, That upon such bond being executed, the commissioners or principal officers of the revenue at the respective ports, shall cause all such tobacco to be put into ware-houses under the King’s and merchant’s locks, such merchant or merchants, or his or their servants to have free access into said ware-houses at all seasonable rimes, and the custom-house officers are hereby required to attend without fee or reward.

V. And be it further enacted, That the commissioners of his Majesty's revenue, or any three of them for the time being, are hereby authorized and empowered, out of any of the subsidies, customs, duties, or imposts paid, by virtue, or in pursuance of any act or acts of parliament of force in this kingdom, upon You XIII- 6 I the

494 twenty sixth Year of George III.

A. X), the importation of tobacco into the fame, to provide from time to time as they 1786# fasrtl deem neccfljry, a warc-house or warc-houses at each and every of the

Chap. 6. herein respective enumerated ports, in which ware-house or warc-houses, ami u no other, all such tobacco Co as aforesaid imported or brought into this kingdom,

and fp bonded for as aforesaid, shall be so deposited and secured as aforesaid, and a]) tobacco, so deposited and secured, shall be charged and pay such duty as aforesaid, according to the net weight thereof, at the time when such tobacco shall be fold, or delivered out of such (lores as aforesaid.

VI. And be it further enacted, That the person or persons importing tobacco, shall respectively bear all the charges and expences incurred in any way, by unfiiipping, bringing, carrying, or conveying any tobacco from the several and respective ships, so importing the fame, to the respective ware-houses in which the fame tobacco is to be so deposited as aforesaid; or in the bringing, carrying, or conveying the tobacco from such respective ware-houses, to and on boatd the several and respective ships in which the same shall be respectively exported to foreign parts, favc and except the charges and expences of paying the revenue officers under whose special care the said tobacco shall be so respectively conveyed, either from the ship to the ware-house on importation, or from the ware-house to the ship on exportation j any law, custom, or usage to the contrary notvith* (landing.

VII. And be it further enacted, That the respective proprietors of the tobacco so to be brought as aforesaid to the respective ware-houses before mentioned, shall be at the expence of dripping or taking the hogsheads, in which the tobacco shall be so imported as aforesaid, from the tobacco before the fame shall be so weighed as aforesaid.

VIII. And be it further enacted, That in case any tobacco which shall have been entered, and the duty thereon paid or secured in maimer aforesaid, shall from and after the twenty fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty fix, be exported from this kingdom, the exporter shall upon the exportation thereof, within three years from the importation, on producing a proper debenture to be made out for that purpose, be paid, or allowed to draw back the whole net duty actually paid at or after the importation of such quantity so exported, or to have the bond given on importation vacated, or allowance made by entry on the back of such bond, for such quantity of tobacco as shall be so exported, as the case shall be; any law or custom to the contrary notwithstanding.

IX. And be it further enacted, That if the importer or importers of such tobacco, as shall be so lodged in ware-houses as aforesaid, shall not within the said space of fifteen months, by payment of the said duties so bonded for, or by debentures upon exportation of such tobacco, discharge his or their obligations, hut that the tobacco, or any part thereof, shall continue and be dill remaining in the said ware-houses for want of payment of any of the duties due thereon; in such case it shall and may be lawful for the said commissioners or principal officers of your Majesty's revenue for the time being at the respective ports, and they are hereby empowered to cause the said tobacco so remaining to be publicity sold by inch of candle, first giving the proprietor or proprietors thereof, fourteen days notice personally, or by leaving a notice in writing at the place of such proprietor’s Iaft abode, the product thereof, after such falc, first to be applied to payment of the said bond, storage, and all other charges which may have been incurred, and the overplus, if any, to be rendered and paid to the proprietor, or other person lawfully authorized to receive the same.
