LXIX. And whereas very great injuries have been done to fltips and vessels coming into, and moored in the said harbour or bay of Dublin, and the said river Anna Liffey, and the said harbour of Dunleary, by wicked and evil minded persons cutting away the buoys, and buoy-ropes from the anchors of such fiiips and vessels, and also the ropes and hawsers by which fltips and vessels are moored jnd fattened to their anchors, and otherwise within the said harbour, bay, and river; and it also frequently happens, that when a vessel through difrrefs or other cause, flips or cuts her cable, and leaves her anchor behind with a buoy fattened thereto, such buoy, and the rope by which the fame is fattened, are cut away for the purpose of preventing the owner of such anchor from finding the fame, and the persons who cut away such buoy and buoy-rope, take private marks of the place where they find the fame, so as to be able with certainty to know where such anchor lies, and thereby to extort an extravagant reward for finding the fame: and whereas the persons guilty of such nefarious practices, frequently escape punishment, by reason of the matters and crews of such vessels being obliged to fail from this kingdom, and on that account, being prevented from attending the prosecution of such persons by the ordinary course of law -. for remedy whereof, and in order as effectually as possible to prevent such flagitious and dangerous acts, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful to and for any of his Majesty's subjects whatsoever, to seize and take into

LXXXIV. And whereas by means of such change, when made, the present intercourse between Ringfcnd and Iriflitown, and the place called Sandymount, and other places southward and south-west of the said course or canal, will he totally prevented, to the great inconvenience and injury of the many inhabitants of the said places, and the adjacent grounds, and the great number of inhabitants of Ringfend and Iriflitown will be deprived of the salutary benefit of fresh and pure water, by means of the said change, unless they are otherwise supplied with water from the said canal: and whereas the bridge at Ringfend over the said river Dodder, is in a ruinous condition, and would require to lie rebuilt, if the course of said river were not to be turned away from the said bridge, and the rebuilding thereof would be a necessary charge on the county of the city of Dublin: be it further enacted, That the grand jury of the city of Dublin do, and shall, in the term next after the lines for the said intended course or canal shall be marked out, cause to be presented and ralfed upon th e county of the said city of Dublin at large, in the manner prescribed by the laws now in force for raising money by presentment for building bridges in counties, a sum of money sufficient for building and erecting acrol's the said intended course or canal on a line as directly as conveniently may be, from Iriflitown to Sandymount, a bridge of stone, sand, and mortar, sufficiently wide for horses, carriages, and passengers, to pass and repass between the places aforesaid.

LXXXV. And be it further enacted, That the inhabitants of Ringfend and Iriflitown, shall have and receive a supply of fresh water from the said river Dodder, or new cut or canal, to the centre of each of them, so as that the inhabitants may supply themselves at all times with fresh water; provided they shall by proper sewers, let the superabundant water discharge itself into the Liffey in a convenient manner. An Act for continuing and amending several Laws relating to His Majestys Revenue, and for the more cffe3ually preventing of Frauds therein, and for other Purposes therein mentioned.

II. And for better preventing frauds in re-landing in this kingdom any goods which shall be entitled to a drawback or bounty on exportation from hence to Great Britain: be it further enacted, That from and after the passing of this act, no' drawback or bounty shall be allowed or paid for any goods exported or entered for exportation from this kingdom to Great Britain (except for goods which may perish at sea, or be taken by an enemy or pirate, and which shall be proved to the satisfaction of the commissioners of his Majesty's revenue to have done so) until a certificate shall be produced under the hands and seals of office of the collector and comptroller, or other principal officer of the culloms for the port where such goods shall be landed in Great Britain, testifying the landing thereof, which certificate shall also express the exact weight, measure, or quantity of the goods so landed, with the number and marks of the calks, bales, or other packages in which such goods shall be contained.

XXXVI. And be it further enacted, That it shall and may be lawful for the said commissioners and justices acting under this act, or any of them, at any time to demand from any victualler or other person felling beer, ale, or spirituous liquors, his or her license for felling beer, ale, or spirituous liquors; and every such person shall, upon fitch demand produce his or her license on pain of forfeiting the sum of ten pounds for every time he or flic shall neglect or refuse to produce his or her license as aforesaid, and in default of paying such fine, shall be committed to the common gaol for any time not less than one, or more than three months.

XXXVII. And be it further enacted, That if any victualler, or other person felling or licensed to fell beer, ale, or spirituous liquors, or any person or persons aiding and assisting such victualler or person licensed as aforesaid, shall prevent and endeavour to prevent by threats or violence the said commissioners, or any of them, or such petty constable, chief constable, or high constable as aforesaid, from entering any such dwelling house or place, and searching for such idle and disorderly persons, or shall assault or otherwise refill such commissioner or commissioners, or such petty constable, chief constable, or high constable, every such person so offending, shall, upon conviction of any such offence, forfeit and pay the sum of one hundred pounds.

XLI. And be it further enacted, That all night-walkers, all suspicious persons in the day-time, loitering about without having any visible means of maintaining themselves, and all persons not giving a satisfactory account of themselves, all persons notoriously suspected of being thieves, and all persons gaming or tippling in the publick streets, by-places or fields, shall and may be apprehended by any petty contlable, chief constable, or high constable, duly appointed by the said commissioners, or by any constable, watchman, or beadle, and carried before a justice of the peace; and if such perl'on shall not give sufficient surety for his or her good behaviour, he, she, or they shall be adjudged, deemed, and taken to.be a rogue and vagabond within the intent and meaning of Hie statutes in that behalf made in this kingdom; and every justice of the peace as often as any such offender shall be brought before him and committed for want of such sureties as aforesaid, shall immediately give notice thereof to the said commissioners; and if any perl'on or persons apprehended as aforesaid, shall be friendlels, and deferred boys under age of fourteen years, it shall be lawful for the said commissioners, or any of them, at any time before any such person or persons shall be discharged, to tender him or them to the governors of the marine hospital, in order to be placed by them in the sea service, or otherwise to put him or them out in some ul'eful calling, occupation, or employment, according to the age and circumstances of the person, and as may l'eem 1110ft convenient and practicable to the said commissioners, or any of them.

XLII. And whereas the business of a justice of the peace within the said district, cannot be transacted in the private houses of such justices, with equal advantage to the publick, as in an oflice appointed for that purpose only: and whereas it is necessary to provide for the due and regular attendance of fit and able magistrates at such publick offices as aforesaid: be it therefore enacted, That a publick office for transacting the business of the justice of the peace, shall be appointed in each and every of the aforesaid divisions by the said commissioners of the police; and that two houses of corredkion shall be erected within the said district, and that the said publick offices for the said divisions, and the said houses of correction, shall be severally and respectively in such streets and places as to the said commissioners shall feein most expedient.

LXVI. And be it also further enacted, That the printed proclamation wherein such person and persons are named or mentioned to be presented or indicted by the grand jury of any county, county of any city or town in this kingdom, at the general a/fizes or quarter sessions, to be guilty of the offences aforesaid, shall be taken, deemed, and adjudged sufficient evidence against such person and persons; and that the justices of oyer and terminer, and general gaol delivery, the several judges of assize, and justices at sessions before whom any person or persons convicted of any crime or crimes for which the person or persons convicted is or are, or shall be liable to transportation, shall and may order that such person or persons be transported, either to any of his Majesty's plantations or settlements in America, or to such other place or places not in Europe, as such judges or justices respectively shall order and direct; any law, statute, or usage to the contrary notwithstanding.

LXVII. And whereas the laws in being are not sufficient to provide for the speedy transportation of felons under sentence, rule, or order of transportation, and from the difficulty of procuring ships and vessels trading to his Majesty's plantations to convey such felons thereto, the several counties in which such felons have been convicted and confined, have been at considerable expence in the support and maintenance of such felons during their confinement, and in the transmission of such persons to the sea-ports from which they have been transported, and in contrafting for their transportation: therefore be it enacted, That the clerks of the crown, and clerks of the peace in the several counties in this kingdom, shall make out and sign certificates of the names of every person remaining in the gaol or gaols of the several counties under any rule, sentence, or order of transportion, made by the judges presiding respectively-in the courts wherein ifock clerks of the crown or peace respectively officiated, specilying therein the particular offences for which such persons were respectively ordered to be transported.; which certificates shall within thirty days after the last day of every a/fizes or gaol delivery, or quarter-sessions respectively, as the case may happen, be transmitted by the several clerks of the crown, and clerks of the peace respectively, to the lord lieutenant or other chief governor or governors of tills kingdom for the time being.

XI. And whereas it is equally correspondent with the feelings of humanity, and requisite to the well being and safety of the community at large,'that particular attention Ihotild be paid to the health of all persons confined in the several prisons of this.metropolis: be it therefore enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful for the term grand jury of the county of the city of Dublin, at every liafter term, to appoint a regularly bred physician to the office of physician to the gaols, houses of correction, marshalseas, and other public prisons within the county of the city aforesaid, and the liberties thereunto adjoining, save and except his Majesty's gaol of Newgate, during the continuance in office of the present inspector and physician of the said gaol of Newgate.

XII. Provided always, That the physician so appointed, shall be approved of by his Majesty's court of king’s bench.

XIII. And be it further enacted, That the said physician shall, and he is hereby required to visit every gaol and house of correction, marshalsea, and other public prison within the said city and the liberties thereunto adjoining, except as before excepted, twice at least in every week, and oftener if necessary, and to prescribe for all prisoners confined therein, such medicines and sustenance as may appear to him conducive to their recovery.

XIV. And whereas such medical attendance will necessarily be very laborious and painful: be it therefore enacted, That it shall and may>be lawful for the term grand jury aforesaid, at every Easter and Michaelmas term in each year after such appointment, to present a sum not exceeding fifty pounds sterling, at each of the said terms, a6 a recompence for such attendance.

XV. Provided always, That it shall not be lawful fer the grand jury aforesaid, to make such preferments, unless laid physician shall have first.produced.a certificate signed by the inspector of the prisons of the county of the city aforesaid, for the time being, letting forth that the said physician has duly fulfilled the several duties required by this act, and the said inspector of the prisons, is hereby required to grant the said certificate, unless he shall be able to make it appear by affidavit to his Majesty's court of king’s bend), that the physician aforesaid has rieglefted the duties of his office as herein directed, in which case the said inspector. is hereby required to refuse the said certificate, and to assign his reasons accordingly.

CHAP. XXVIII.

An Act for Building a Bridge over ibe Northern Channel of the River Lee, in the City of Cork, and Suburbs thereof, and for other Purposes relative to the said City.

WHEREAS the city of Cork, and the suburbs thereof, are by the extenfien of commerce considerably encreased, and are likely to encrease: and whereas there is no communication or passage from the country into the said city, on the north fide thereof, for goods, cattle, carriages, or travellers, except by one bridge called North- Bridge: be it therefore enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That the mayor, recorder, aldermen, and such of the burgesses as are or shall be of the common council, and also the two citizens representing' the said city in parliament, and the common speaker of said city, all for the time being, and the several persons herein after named, The per- to wit, Humphry Crowly, esquire, John Thompson Burgess, John mentioned1 Digby,. Richard Perry, and John Pedder of the city of Cork, ef-comimiTioacrd fiu'ires’ doctor John Longfield, William Hare, Cooper Penrose, for designins, archdeacon Chambre Corker, George Newfom, John Lapp, Ri-oreAhenwr chard Hare, senior, and Pope Gray, esquires, shall be and arc tee. hereby appointed commissioners, with full power and authority for designing, making, erecting, and building one bridge below the present bridge over the northern branch or channel of the said liver Lee, running through the said city and suburbs thereof, and that it shall and may be lawful to and for the said commissioners, or their successors, or any five or more of them, to design, assign, and lay out and appoint in what manner said bridge shall be built, and over what particular part of said river, which appointment,

II. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That as soon as the said commissioners shall, as aforesaid, have assigned, design-cd, and appointed how and in what manner the aforesaid bridge shall be built, and over what particular part of the said river Lee, and that such designation and appointment Avail be confirmed as aforesaid, the said commissioners before they shall proceed or have power to proceed to build such bridge, shall summon the owners and all persons whatsoever having or claiming any estate, right, title, or interest in and to the two ferries plying for hire over the said north branch of the river Lee, one from the Custom-house to the opposite fide of said river, and the other from the Coal-quay to the opposite fide, to meet the said commissioners, at such time and place in said city as shall be mentioned in such summons, in order to agree with the said several persons either for the purchase of their respective estate, right, title, term, and interest in and to the said ferries, or to make them recompence for any damage or loss that may he sustained by them respectively- by the building such bridge at the election of such owners, proprietors, or persons respectively claiming such right, title, or interest in or to such ferries, which summons shall be served upon, or left at the dwelling-house of such person or persons respectively, ten days at least before they Avail be required to meet said commissioners; and in case the said commissioners cannot at such meeting agree with and satisfy the said several persons for the purchase of their respective estates, right, title, term, and interest in said ferries, or for any damage or loss that they may respectively sustain by the building of such bridge, that then, a jury shall be summoned to value the same as herein after mentioned.

II. And whereas by an act of Parliament made 111 the tenth nibution. year of the reign of his late Majesty king Charles the first, enti- '=Ch. i. tied. An act for the contentaiion of debts upon execution, a remedy is provided for conufees in cases where the lands, tenements, or hereditaments taken by them in execution shall be evicted before they shall have levied their whole debt and damages, by issuing a new feire facias for the recovery of the residue of such debt and damages, but it bath been holden that the said act doth not extend to cases where all the lands, tenements, or hereditaments or the whole estate of the conufee in them is not evlfted; for remedy whereof, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said act shall be construed to extend to all cases where any of the lands, tenements, or hereditaments so taken in execution, or any part of the estate or interest of the conufee therein shall be evicted.

whereas doubts have arisen whether the said lord mayor, Sheriffs, harbour, commons, and citizens, or the committee appointed by them as aforesaid, were empowered by the said act, or any other act of Parliament, to charge the funds granted to them by act of Parliament, with the money so borrowed: and whereas it is just and reasonable, that the several fair creditors who lent their money for this useful purpose should be repaid the fame; and that all sums of money now justly due for principal or filtered, or which may hereafter become due for interest thereof, should he a charge and lien upon the funds appropriated by any act or acts of Parliament, to the improvement of the port, harbour, or river of Dublin, for the improvement of which such sums have been expended: be it therefore enacted, That all and every the just debt and debts which have been contrafted by the said lord mayor, sheriffs, commons, and citizens of the city of Dublin, or the committee appointed by them, for carrying on the business of the ballast-office, for the purposeB aforesaid, and shall be certified to have been applied to such purposes, shall be a charge and lien upon all and every the fund or funds which are already or may hereafter be granted by any act or acts of Parliament, for the purpose of improving the port, harbour, and river of Dublin, and they are hereby made a charge and lien upon such funds.

CHAP. XXXVII.

An Act for the more efficSual Punishment of Persons who shall attain., or attempt to attain, Possession of Money or Goods by false Pretenies, or b'y threats.

[Preamble.]

Persons who from ill June, obtain by false pretences as hetein, money, goods, See. or (end letters with that intent,

WHEREAS divers evil disposed persons have frequently by various subtle stratagems and devices fraudulently, or by threats, obtained divers sums of money, goods, wares, and merchandizes,- to the great injury of the persons so defrauded, and to the manifest prejudice of trade and credit: Therefore for the punishing of all such offenders, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the first day of June next, if any person or persons knowingly or designedly, by false pretence or pretences, shall obtain from any person, money, goods, wares, or merchandizes, with intent to cheat or defraud any person of the fame, or shall knowingly fend or deliver any letter, or writing, with or without a name

CHAP. XXXIX.

An Act to prevent the Practice of fraudulently buying and selling of Light Gold Coin in this Kingdom.

[Preamble.]

From pnf-ting this act Tlo pcifon shall buy any guinea or half guinea for left tliiM (he legal currency* tin* less it be cut as herein, pci a'ty not more than 20l. nor less than 5l.

WHEREAS the manner of buying and selling the gold coin of Great Britain, current in this kingdom, called guineas and half guineas, which are deficient in weight, hath been found injurious to the publick, in as much that such guineas and half guineas after they have been so bought are frequently again circulated through this kingdom: for prevention whereof, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the passing of this act, no person whatsoever shall buy any guinea or half guinea for a less sum than the legal currency at the time the same shall be bought, such legal currency of such guinea being at the present time one pound two shillings and nine pence, and the legal currency of such half guinea, being at the present time eleven shillings and four pence halfpenny, unless such guinea or half guinea at the time the same shall be bought being lighter than the legal weight, shall be cut in the presence of the person or persons buying and person or persons felling the fame in such manner that such cut be of the" length of at least one quarter of the diameter of such guinea or -half guinea; and if any person or persons shall offend contrary to the true intent and meaning hereof, every such person being thereof convicted upon the oath of one or more credible witness or witnesses before any justice of the peace of the county or city of this kingdom in which the offence shall he committed, shall, for every 5 such

the twenty sixth Year of George III.

such offence forfeit a sura not more than twenty pounds, nor lcfs than five pounds, to be levied by distress and saie of the goods and chattels of the offender, by warrant under the hand and seal of such justice, one moiety whereof shall go to the person filing for the fame, and the other moiety to the poor of the parish in which such offence or offences shall be committed.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That whenever any person shall be convicted by due course of law of buying such light gold as aforesaid, contrary to this act, to the amount of twenty guineas, or more, it shall and may be lawful for the court before whom the said person shall be so convicted, to fine the person so convicted in any sum not exceeding five hundred pounds, and to imprison every such person until the said fine shall be paid.

XXVIII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall he lawful for the grand juries of said county of the said city to appoint an overseer or overseers for the building or repairing of any session-house, gaol, sheriffs gaol for' debtors, work-house, bridge, gullet, pipe, or wall necessary for the support of any road, or for the making, repairing, or preferring of any road in said county of said city, and that no treasurer, collector, or other person receiving the publick money, shall on any account be named or appointed an overseer in any preferment in said city.

XXIX. And for the purpose of preventing the many injuries 'to the publick roads committed in parts of the county of the said city and liberties thereof: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the passing of this act, all and every person or persons who shall knowingly destroy or injure any rampart, buttress, wall, bridge, abuttment, pavement, or other work, which hath been, or shall be erected or made to protect or fortify any road, or to defend or preserve the fame from the violence of the sea, or other water; or shall Ideal, fell, or carry away any stones, timber, or other materials which shall compose the fame, Dial! upon being duly convicted thereof according to law, he sentenced to pay a fine not exceeding the sum of fifty pounds, or be imprisoned at the discretion of the judge before whom such person or persons shall be found guilty, for any space of time not exceeding three months; and if any stones, timber, or other materials which Hull compose any of the works aforesaid, and be taken therefrom as aforesaid, shall he found in the possession of any person, such possession shall he prima facia preemptive evidence that such stones, timber, or other materials so taken away, and found in the possession of such person as aforesaid, hath or have been so taken, stolen, or carried away hv the person in whose possession the same shall have been so found, and that proof of the innocence of such person shall lie upon the person or persons in -whose possession the same shall have been so found.

XLII. And whereas from the uncertainty as to the boundaries of the county of the city of Dublin, and the county of Dublin, it has been found extremely difficult in many cases to execute the ordinary process of the law, whereby many persons have escaped punishment, and the creditors have been defrauded or greatly delayed in the recovery of their debts, and other inconvenieucies have arisen: and whereas the mode of proceeding for profecu-ting a commission of perambulation, in order to have the said boundaries ascertained, on account of the number of persons who are necessary to be made parties to any suit to be commenced for that purpose, would be both tedious and expensive, for affording sufficient remedy in the premisses, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the lord Lord dun-chancellor of Ireland, on a petition to be preferred to him in the a commission high court of Chancery, by the grand jury of the county, or county of the city of Dublin, or by either of them, for the time enuining the being, praying to have the boundaries between the said counties bounds bo-enquired into and ascertained, after notice shall have been given in such publick manner as the lord chancellor shall direct, of such city of Dub-petition or petitions being preferred, and after hearing what may be bertics, and said, touching the matter of said petition, by the persons who may think themselves affected thereby, or their council; CHAP. XLIII.

An Act to establish the Business of a Pawnbroker, arid-to authorize such Persons as fall be duly qualified to carry on the fame,

to lend Money on Pawns or Pledges, and to receive Interesl at a higher 'Rate than heretofore was recoverable by Law.

Preamble, T Y7HERE-AS lending money In small Turns on pledges or pawns would prove extremely convenient and advantageous to the lower order of traders, artificers, and others, provided that such borrowers were not liable to imposition or extortion for un-jeasonable filtered money, or for any unwarrantable charge or demand whatsoever: and whereas the heft mode of obtaining such convenience and advantage for such borrowers, -would be to establish the business of, a, pawnbroker by law, on fitch a footing, and under such regulations as would encourage persons of good repute and property to embark therein, as the means of earning a sufficient, honed, and proper livelihood adequate to the risque, trouble, and necessary expellees of carrying on the said business: may-it therefore please your Majesty, that it may be enacted, and be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice, and confc-nt of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the autho-from ift rity of the fame, That it shall be lawful from and after the first qualified per- day of May, one thousand seven hundred and eighty fix, for all CTdfrtw'bu- anc* evcT Peri°n and persons who shall be duly qualified and ii-Cmfsofa censed to use, or,exercise the trade or bufir.efs of a pawnbroker.

agreeably to the regulations hereafter mentioned, and none others, to demand, receive, and take off and from all and every person or persons applying or offering to pledge or pawn any goods or chat- 1 ' tclt

And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That each and every pawnbroker shall and is hereby required to procure and give a new or fresh security in the manner and for the purposes aforesaid, upon the death or failure of any furcty who had executed a bond as aforesaid, for the due performance of such pawnbroker; and in case any such pawnbroker shall knowingly or wilfully neglect to give such new or fresh surety as aforesaid, within three months after such death or failure of any person who then is or was his or her surety as aforesaid, such pawnbroker so neglecting, and proof thereof being duly made before any'two justices of the peace of the county, city, borough, or town corporate, wherein such pawnbroker shall carry on his or her said business, for each and every such neglect shall be fined, and forfeit for the use of the poor of the parish wherein he or she re-fides, any film not lei's than five pounds sterling, or more than twenty pounds sterling, which fine or forfeiture when received shall be paid to the minister or church-wardens of said parish for the poor thereof; and in case the said fine shall not be paid as aforesaid, within ten days after such conviction, then it shall and may be lawful to and for such justices as aforesaid, and they are hereby authorized and required so to do, to grant a warrant under their hands and seals to levy the amount of such fine by distress and sale of such pawnbroker’s goods.

CHAP. XLIV.

An Act for the Relief of Persons who have omitted to qualify them-

filvcs according to Law.

WHEREAS several persons well affected to his Majesty's government, and to the church of Ireland as by law established, may through igno-ranee have neglected, or been prevented by fiefcness or other unavoidable causes, from taking and subscribing the oaths, and from making, taking, and subscribing the declaration, and from receiving the sacrament of the Lord’s supper, and delivering a certificate thereof, according to the directions of an act made in this kingdom, in the second year of the reign of Iter late Majesty Queen Anne, entitled, An act to prevent the further grenvtb of popery, or feme other act or acts now in force in this kingdom, and may thereby have incurred great penalties: therefore, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all and every person and persons who have incurred any penalties or incapacities in the said act, entitled, An act to prevent the further growth of popery^ mentioned, or any other ad, -by neglecting to qualify themselves according to tile said act or acts, shall be and are hereby indemnified, freed, and discharged, of and from all incapacities, disabilities, forfeitures, and penalties incurred by reason of such omission or neglect as aforesaid, and that no act or acts done by them or any of them, and not yet avoided, shall be questioned or avoided by reason of such neglect or omission, but nil such acts shall be and are hereby declared and enacted to be as good and effectual as if all and every such person and persons had taken and subscribed the said oaths, and received the said sacrament, and delivered the certificates thereof, and made, repeated, and subscribed said declaration, at such time, place, and manner as is therein mentioned, any thing in the said act to the contrary notwithstanding.

II. Provided always, That such person or persons who (after accepting any office, place, or employment, or undertaking my profession, or thing, on account of which such qualification ought to have been had, and is required) hath or have taken and subscribed the said oaths, or made, subscribed, and repeated the said declaration, and who on or before the sixth day of November next, shall take and subscribe the said oaths, and make, repeat, and subscribe the said declaration in such manner and form, and in fuel) place and places, as are directed and appointed by the said act, to prevent the further growth of popery, on or before the sixth day of November, one thousand seven hundred and eighty fix.

III. And whereas some persons who have been elected, and in the usual manner sworn into the office of ffierlff or fheriiL of different cities in this kingdom, may have omitted merely through the mtlhkc of the persons authorized to admit them into office, to take the oath prescribed to be taken by them, by an act passed in the twenty fifth year of the reign of his present Majesty, entitled, An act to amend an act passed in the twelfth year of his late Majesty George the firs, entitled, An act for better regulating the office of sheriffs, and for ascertainitig their fees, and the fees fsr sting their patents, and puffing their accounts: be it there-3 fore

An Act for granting the Sum of Nine Thousand Pounds to the Incorporated Society, for supporting the Protcfant Charter Schools of this Kingdom.

WHEREAS by an act passed in this kingdom this present session of Parliament, entitled, An act for granting unto ’’""Me. his Majesty, his heirs and successors, an additional duty on wine, bides, beer, ale, and other goods and merchandizes therein mentioned; and for prohibiting the importation of all gold and silver lace, and of all cambricks and lawns, except of the manufacture of Great Britain; and of all bops, except of the growth of Great Britain and the British plantations; and of all glass, except from Great Britain-, the sum of seventy-one thousand six hundred pounds was granted to be applied in such manner as parliament should direct, for the advancement of fisheries, trade, and manufactures, and the maintenance of hospitals, charities, and publick inliitutions, and the further improvement of this kingdom, by building churches and other publick works: be it enacted by the king’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That nine thousand pounds, part of the said sum of seventy-one thousand six hundred the inmrpo-pounds, be granted to the incorporated society, as a full provision y^f'7 for supporting the protestant charter schools of this kingdom, for one year, from the twenty-fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-six, to the twenty-fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-seven; the said sum of nine thousand pounds to be paid by the vice-treasurer or vice-treasurers, receiver-general or reccivers-general of this kingdom, his or their deputy or deputies, without any further or other warrant, to be filed for, had, or obtained in that behalf.

XVI. And whereas in the river Bandon in the county of Cork, salmon continue 'in season from the first day of March to the first day of November: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful for the proprietors and farmers of fisheries on said river to fish therein for salmon from the first day of March to the first day of November in every year, notwithstanding any act heretofore made to the contrary.

XVII. And whereas salmon are in season in the river Slaney from March to October: be it therefore enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful to take salmon in the river Slaney from the twenty-fifth day of March to the first day of November in-every year; any act heretofore passed to the contrary -notwithstanding.

II. XXII. Provided always, That nothing herein contained shall extend to enable the said company to draw off from the river Lifley, more water than shall be sufficient for the purpose of the said navigation, and shall not extend to enable them to draw off water for the fake of felling or letting out such water, it being the true intent and meaning of this act, that no water shall be fold, let, or disposed of, other than such as may happen from a casual redundancy in the said canal, to be made in pursuance of this act.

XXIII. And whereas the company of undertakers of the grand canal, have opened a cut for a short way from Ofborftown-brjdge, into the main trunk of the said canal, and have purchased the lands adjacent thereto, and right of the water which there falls into the canal, and the said company of undertakers of the grand canal, have consented to transfer the same to the said county Kildare company: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said cut, and the use of the said water, together with all the land and banks contiguous thereto, now the property of the said company of undertakers of the grand canal, shall, immediately after the passing of this act, be vested in the said county Kildare company: provided that it shall not be lawful for the said county Kildare company, to divert away any part of the water to which the said company of undertakers of the grand canal are now entitled, on any account, or under any pretence whatsoever, unless -with the consent of the said company of undertakers of the grand canal.

X. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That each of the said commissioners herein named, or who hereafter shall be appointed by virtue of this act, shall be paid out of the funds hereby arising, twenty shillings for every day on which not lei's than four of the said commissioners, exclusive of directors, shall be present during the time the business of such meeting shall be transacting, of which attendances entries shall be made each day by the secretary or clerk to the corporation in the book wherein their proceedings shall be entered, and the number of attendances of each commissioner shall be ascertained thereby, such registry of the attendance of the commissioners to be verified upon oath, by the secretary or clerk before the commissioners of imprest accounts at the time the accounts of the corporation shall be passed, and the commissioners paid accordingly.

And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons shall wilfully or maliciously break, throw down, or extinguish any globe, or any lamp which is or shall he eroded or placed in any of the streets, squares, lanes, courts, alleys, or yards, or on any of the quays, bridges, or other passages within the limits of this act, or Until wilfully or maliciously damage the polls, iron, or other furniture thereof, every person so offending, or who shall aid, abet, or assist in the -fame, upon conviction upon oath of one or more witness or tvitnelTes before the lord mayor or any other magistrate of the said city, or before any three or more of the said directors and -commissioners, shall forfeit and pay any sum, not exceeding five pounds, nor less than five findings; and if such fine or fines shall not be paid upon conviction, that then it shall and may be lawful to and for the said lord mayor, or other magistrate, or for the directors and commissioners before whom such oflender o-offenders shall he convicted, to commit him, her, or them 1.1 the house of correction, for any space of time not less than fourteen days, nor exceeding one month.

C.XXVIII.
